case_vignette: A 65-year-old man is brought into the emergency department by his wife for slurred speech and right-sided weakness. The patient has a significant past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The wife reports her husband went to bed last night normally but woke up this morning with the symptoms mentioned. Physical examination shows right-sided hemiparesis along with the loss of vibration and proprioception. Cranial nerve examination shows a deviated tongue to the left.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm having trouble speaking clearly and my right side feels weak.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I woke up this morning with these symptoms.
Have you had any similar symptoms in the past?
No, this is the first time this has happened to me.
Do you have any chronic medical conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
I have high blood pressure and high cholesterol.
Have you ever been diagnosed with or treated for diabetes or heart disease?
No, I have not been treated for diabetes or heart disease.
Are you experiencing any other symptoms like visual disturbances, headache, or difficulty understanding others?
No, just the slurred speech and weakness on my right side.
Is there any family history of stroke or other neurological conditions?
I'm not sure; we haven't talked about that in my family.
How old are you and what is your sex?
I am a 65-year-old man.
Final Diagnosis: Ischemic Stroke

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency room with slurred speech and weakness on his right side. He reports that this is the first time he has experienced these symptoms. The patient has a history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol but has not been treated for diabetes or heart disease. There is no mention of a family history of similar symptoms.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is a left-sided ischemic stroke, specifically involving the anterior circulation, likely the middle cerebral artery territory.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have slurred speech and my right side feels weak.
When did you first notice these symptoms?
I woke up this morning with these symptoms.
Do you have any other symptoms like vision problems, headache, or difficulty walking?
I'm not having vision problems or a headache, but I do have trouble with my balance and walking because of my weakness.
Have you had any similar episodes in the past, or is this the first time?
This is the first time this has happened to me.
How old are you and are you currently on any medication?
I am 65 years old and yes, I take medication for high blood pressure and cholesterol.
Do you have a history of any other medical conditions such as diabetes, heart disease, or previous strokes?
No, I only have a history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol.
Have you experienced any recent head trauma or injuries?
No, I haven't had any head injuries recently.
Is there any family history of stroke, heart disease, or other neurological conditions?
I don't know, you didn't tell me about my family's medical history.
Is there a known family history of stroke, heart disease, or other neurological conditions that you are aware of?
I don’t know; we haven’t talked about my family’s medical history.
Are you currently experiencing any difficulty with your vision or facial drooping on one side?
No, my vision is fine and there's no drooping on my face.

Given the sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech, without head trauma or additional neurological findings, and considering your age and medical history:

**Final Diagnosis: Stroke, likely ischemic in nature.**

I woke up this morning with these symptoms.

trial_4.summarized_conversation: A patient presented to the emergency room with difficulty speaking clearly and weakness on the right side of their body. They reported that the symptoms began suddenly when they woke up that morning. The patient denied any recent head injuries or trauma, but mentioned a history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol. They were unable to provide information about their current medications or family medical history. The patient also denied any visual disturbances or difficulty understanding speech, but did report feeling weak on one side. They had not attempted to walk yet, but expressed concern about the weakness they were experiencing.
trial_4.vignette_frq: Left-sided ischemic stroke involving the anterior circulation, likely the middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory.
